awd_titl_txt: Collaborative LTREB Proposal:   Will increases in dissolved organic matter accelerate a shift in trophic status through anoxia-driven positive feedbacks in an oligotrophic lake?
awd_abstract_narration:
Lakes provide many services to society, such as clean drinking water and productive fisheries. Many lakes, however, are now experiencing increased input of carbon and nutrients, warming temperatures, and declining ice cover, which may reduce water quality or cause blooms of potentially harmful algae. Specifically, many lakes across the United States are experiencing increased browning due to high loading of organic matter leached from land plants. Browning reduces water clarity and interferes with drinking water management practices. In addition, it can cause other changes that may lead to rapid long-term declines in water quality. This research will test the hypothesis that browning may reduce oxygen concentrations in lakes. Low oxygen can cause nutrient release from lake sediments that may increase algae blooms, leading to lake eutrophication. Understanding the effects of browning will increase knowledge of lake ecosystems, and improve forecasts of how lakes will change as their surrounding environments change.  This research will also train graduate and undergraduate students, and will lead to better public understanding of threats to lake water quality.

Ecological tipping points are of vital interest as anthropogenic activities rapidly transform natural ecosystems. Changes in dissolved organic matter (DOM) represent one important potential driver of tipping points in aquatic ecosystems. This project will investigate whether increases in terrestrial DOM loading can push clear-water oligotrophic lakes beyond a critical tipping point by stimulating hypolimnetic anoxia and sediment DOM and phosphorus release, which may initiate a positive feedback loop of decreasing water clarity, stronger thermal stratification, and enhanced hypolimnetic anoxia. This feedback loop accelerates ecological change and ultimately may shift lake trophic status toward greener, mesotrophic to eutrophic as well as browner, dystrophic conditions. This project will extend a long-term data set of water quality variables sampled since the late 1980s in two lakes in or near the Lacawac Sanctuary and Biological Field Station, located in northeastern Pennsylvania. Complementing these long-term observations, experiments and modeling will be carried out to understand feedbacks associated with browning and enhancing understanding of broader patterns of change in inland water bodies. The project will support a regional lake monitoring network in Pennsylvania and closely interface with GLEON, the Global Lake Ecological Observatory Network.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Lacawac Sanctuary and Biological Field Station

por.por_cntn:
The primary goals of this project were to test whether increases in dissolved organic matter (DOM), the brown-colored substance that results from partial decomposition of terrestrial vegetation, can push clear-water lakes beyond a critical tipping point by depleting deep-water oxygen in a lake, causing release of phosphorus (P) from the sediments. This has the potential to create an accelerating feedback loop that can lead to increased algal blooms, decreased water clarity, stronger temperature gradients vertically in the lake, and enhanced deep-water oxygen depletion, with consequences for food webs involving zooplankton, fish, and overall ecosystem structure and function.

Three decades (1988-2021) of data comprising the extensive limnological data set from our core lakes in the Pocono Mountains region of Pennsylvania, USA have been archived in the NSF-supported data repository, EDI (Environmental Data Initiative). This data set comprises one of the world?s largest and most complete data sets with measurements of underwater UV transparency. These data include 48 variables representing the biological, physical, optical, and chemical characteristics of the lakes, with primary foci on the optical characteristics and zooplankton. We also added both our long-term zooplankton data from our core study lakes as well as our global optical and limnological data on over 400 lakes globally to the publicly available EDI data portal.

We worked with collaborators to expand our sampling of the three study lakes to 12 months to measure changes in key variables including temperature, dissolved oxygen (DO), nutrients, DOM, water transparency, and the biological community (phytoplankton, zooplankton, and juvenile fish). We analyzed samples for DOC, absorbance, chlorophyll, phycocyanin, nutrients, and zooplankton abundance. We also carried out high-frequency monitoring of water temperature, dissolved oxygen, and visible light (photosynthetically active radiation, PAR) in the three core lakes. We made several upgrades an automated profiling buoy deployed in Lake Lacawac that provides data on the physical and biological properties of the water column every six hours and near the surface of the lake every15 min.

We made several concerted efforts to integrate our data with similar data from lakes around the world. We led a collaborative publication of temperature profiles from 153 global lakes in 2021, which included our core study lakes. Summer temperature profiles were collected and compiled with over 50 research groups from around the world. These data and a description of this data set were published in Nature Scientific Data, with the data set shared in EDI?s (Environmental Data Initiative) data repository.

We also deployed trail cameras on the shores of all three core study lakes to photograph seasonal changes in ice cover and the lake?s surface to better understand the relationship between variations in the duration of ice cover and oxygen depletion, a key component of the hypothesized feedback loop that we are testing. We added UV radiation and DOM to a current lake model which had previously not been done.

The support provided by this grant led to extensive significant results reported in 27 published manuscripts and other products. Key results included (1) solar degradation of DOM is more important than biological degradation, (2) greater water transparency and exposure to UV and longer wavelength sunlight reduces parasites in the key zooplankton grazer Daphnia, (3) solar UV radiation kills and thus decreases habitat suitability for mosquito larvae, but DOM provides a refuge from UV to increase survival of these important vectors of disease and (4) DOM significantly affects signals from sensors used to detect harmful algal bloom species (cyanobacteria), indicating that additional data processing protocols need to be incorporated to correct for CDOM when estimating cyanobacteria biomass using submersible instruments, (5) DOM significantly mitigates mortality caused by UV exposure in the cladoceran Holopedium glacialis, (6) an analysis of high frequency dissolved oxygen and temperature data demonstrated that lake phenology and a shorter duration of ice cover influences oxygen dynamics in winter more than in summer, and (7) changes in UV, temperature, and dissolved oxygen are altering the vertical habitat availability for the important zooplankton grazer Daphnia. Training of students has also been central to this project and students have been the lead authors as well as coauthors on the many published manuscripts that are the products of this research.

In addition to the scientific publication of these results, we published several papers that reach out to the broader scientific community including two chapters on UV and Optics in the Encyclopedia of Inland Waters, and Williamson contributed to several United Nations Environment Programme Environmental Effects Assessment reports on the effects of UV radiation on aquatic ecosystems. Our intensive long-term and geographically extensive data were used as the foundation for a synthesis paper directed toward lake managers showing the importance of incorporating DOM into the traditional food web (?trophic paradigm?) to more effectively manage lake ecosystems.

 


Last Modified: 09/28/2023
Modified by: Craig E Williamson
